grania had fled with dermat great was his wrath and he called to him his nobles and ordered them with all speed to follow in the track of dermat and grania. then was the wrath of finn so great that he said he would hang his nobles and not one would he spare if they did not again find the track and that with all speed. so being sore afraid they crossed the river and when they had searched they saw the horses one on either side and they found too the spot where dermat and grania had turned from the river. now among the nobles were those who loved dermat and would fain save him from the hate of finn. and they called the hound and told him secretly what he should do. and going in he found dermat and grania asleep and he thrust his head into dermats bosom. then dermat awoke his wife and told her that finn was near. still grania feared greatly but she spake no further for in dermats eyes she read his gloom. for dermat had cleared a space round his hut and around the space had he built the strong fence. then the nobles climbed a high tree and from it did they look within the fence and there they saw dermat and with him a lady. but for their love of dermat did the nobles hide from finn that they had seen his foe. full well i know that dermat is hid behind yonder strong fence. art thou behind the fence i am here and with me is grania but none other shall come hither save with my leave. now in the circle fence were seven doors and at each door did finn place strong men so that dermat should by no means escape. and grania when she heard finns voice was filled with fear and she trembled greatly. then dermat kissed her three times and bade her be of good cheer for all would yet be well. but dermat answered i seek the door guarded by finn and by none other shall i leave this place. then to the third to the fourth and to the fifth door did dermat go and at each was he told how the men without were willing to fight to the death for their love of him. and he went to the seventh door and asked who was without. and no man dared to follow dermat. when grania saw dermat her heart leaped for joy. though he were one hundred years old yet would he be but thirty so soon as he had eaten three of the fairy berries. one eye one red eye gleamed from the middle of his black forehead. and dermat told the giant how he would fain build a hut in the forest and hunt amid the woods. so dermat built a hut near to a clear well and there he and grania lived in peace for many days eating the food of the forest and drinking water from the spring. and when he asked them who they were and whence they came they told how they were enemies that would fain make peace. so they left the palace and journeyed without rest until they came to dermats hut by the clear well. now dermat when he heard footsteps without seized his weapons and going to the door asked of the strangers who they were and whence they came. then dermat said i am not willing to give you my head nor will you find it an easy matter to take it. and he struck the giant a mighty blow to awake him. then dermat sat down to rest. and when they had come back he sent for the princess. so dermat plucked the berries and grania ate and was satisfied. and this he said as though they were free men. they thanked the hero for his words and also for the berries which they could not have got of themselves. then dermat who had watched the game from among the branches overhead spoke aloud to himself the move that should be played. and grania sat by her husband ill at ease. and this time the nobles raised a mighty cheer. and they looked up and through an opening in the branches they beheld dermat kiss grania three times for the princess was in great fear. and he offered great reward to any man that would go up into the tree and bring to him the heros head or force him to come down. and he went up. then nine times did a man of finns army climb the tree and nine times was he thrown to earth and killed by his own friends. and she was a witch. now it chanced on the day that they came thither that dermat hunted alone in the wood. and so sure was his aim that it reached the witch through the leaf and she fell to the ground dead. and there were born unto them one daughter and four sons. now it fell on a day after many years that grania sat as one in a dream. and dermat because of the love he bore grania granted her wish and for a year they were making ready for the great feast. dermat lay down but ere long he again heard the hounds voice. but again grania begged him to lie down and to give no heed to the matter. so dermat lay down and fell into a light sleep and when the hound awakened him the third time it was broad day. and he did not rest till he came to the summit of a hill where he found finn and of him he asked the meaning of the chase. dermat knew no fear of the wild boar and he would not leave the summit of the hill where he stood. so dermat stood alone on the summit of the hill and he knew well it was that he might meet his death that finns men did hunt the boar this day. then as the boar came rushing up the face of the hill dermat let loose his good hound but it seeing the fearful monster fled before him. but it fell harmless to the ground doing the monster no hurt. but so deep was the wound in dermats side that when finn came to him he found the hero near unto death. asked finn. then one of the nobles hearing these words prayed finn that he would let dermat drink from his hands. finn replied i know not of any well on this hill whence i can bring water. no more than nine paces must thou go to reach it. let me i pray thee drink from thine hands. then finn went to the well and in his two hands tightly together did he bring the water towards dermat. i pray thee go once more to the well and bring me to drink or i die. then were raised three long cries of sorrow for dermat who had been dear unto them all. so finn and his nobles left the hill finn leading dermats hound. then they once more followed the king. at length when silence had fallen upon her grief grania arose and ordered that five hundred men should go to the hill and bring to her the body of dermat. then turning to finn she begged of him to leave with her dermats hound. and finn would not. but a noble hearing that grania wished the hound took him from the hand of finn and gave him to the princess. for though i cannot bring him back to life yet each day shall he speak with me for some space. our children

fanny started off early one morning like little red riding hood to visit her grandmother who lives quite at the other end of the village. she went straight on her way and did not see any wolf. they have many things to say to each other for one of them is at the end of lifes voyage and the other is just setting out upon it. just look grandmother however as her habit is eats standing near the corner of the hearth. when they are through with their little talk grandmother gives fanny an apple and some bread. and fanny goes out into the yard where there are trees and grass and flowers and little birds. fanny did not believe there was a prettier yard than this in all the world. already she takes her knife from her pocket to cut her bread as the village people do. fanny could not guess at first what they all wanted. but her heart heard the little birds and she threw them crumbs that scarcely touched the earth before they caught them in the air. fanny saw that the birds were not all of the same nature. they hardly heard her. one is not always heard when one speaks of justice. no matter how she tried she fed the fat at the expense of the thin. it made her very sorry
simple child that she was she did not know it was the way of the world. be a good girl always. she kissed her but fanny stood a while very thoughtful at the threshold. and fanny went away across the fields toward home. she could see the chimney of her house smoking in the distance against the red sunset sky. they loved each other dearly these two. they had been following her. its time to go to bed now. thus fanny came back home to her mother followed by bird music in the air. she slept. she slept and dreamed. she saw the blue bird flying toward the castle of his love. she knew she was not a princess and couldnt expect visits from a prince changed into a bird the color of deep sky. such an one if she should find him she would give not only bread but cakes and kisses too. she would like to see him. and now she does see him all of a sudden he grows bigger and longer his wings change into two arms. she is alone in the little room. they have come from everywhere from greece and rome and blue distant countries to dance with one another. it would not be very amusing to wear a heros dress if you had to show his courage too. the hearts of heroes are torn in all sorts of ways. for the most part they are famous through their misfortunes. if any of them lived happily they are not remembered now. you feel grand just by wearing them. they are going to strike up this piece. there is nothing so pleasant as to see them with their little stiff bodies and their heads so erect. on the other hand she is very well up in sacred history. she would be more surprised to hear that they did not talk any more. and she is right too. animals have always talked and always will talk but they talk only to their friends. to be understood there is nothing like sympathy. mary 
little girls have a natural desire to gather flowers and stars. it was very hard to pick too. she was very pleased and proud at what shed done. but her nurse saw her
and scolded and darted at miss mary seizing her by the arm. there miss mary sits surprised and astonished and thinks it all over. they are large the earth and sky and can amuse a little girl for a while. we must not laugh at her for that one cant learn everything at once. that is why one grows tired of it in spite of its beauty. pan pipes 
three children of the same village peter james and john are standing up looking off at something. it is as god wishes it to be. but what are his two comrades doing they are gazing off into space all three of them. at what the servants from the farm and the mill were pale with longing peter and james were red with joy. little john lost his tongue. everything in the wagon seemed beautiful and precious to them. he has mounted his horse. why it would be hard to say. this red horse was a present from a poor man and maybe there is some secret grace in the gifts of the poor. he is quite far away. little or great we all ride. the sun is shining and the two children sing. they sing like the nightingale because their hearts are gay. the lips that sing them lose their color and are silent one after the other but the songs are always on the wing. it is fear. hes a fierce dog the pig mans. and he is afraid to be afraid. it must be admitted that with no ladies or young maidens in the world men might be less brave. catherines day 
five oclock and miss catherine is receiving her dolls. it is her day at home. the dolls dont talk the little genius that gave them smiles refused them speech. it must have been done for the good of the world for if dolls could talk people would listen to no one else. miss catherine talks for her visitors as well as for herself. she makes the questions and gives the answers. very well madame. oh thats good. and how is your little girl oh what a pity you know madame i had two children last week really that makes four. four or five i dont know which. when you have so many you get confused. you have a very pretty dress on. every evening. i my dear go to a dance every day. thats very amusing. you are as pretty as heart could wish today little one. i like the snow because its so white. oh but this is black snow. that is wrong. but catherine has found this out herself. the little sea dogs 

they are little sailors real little sea dogs every one. their hearts too are of the same stuff as their fathers simple patient and full of courage. since they came into the world they have been simple and big of heart. who has made them so that is why the little sailors in their childish hearts bear such brave thoughts. the little lame prince 
chapter i.
he was the most beautiful prince that ever was born. being a prince people said this and it was true. all the people in the palace were beautifully dressed in the clothes which the queen had given them. everything went on as if she had been present. she picked him up the accident was so slight it seemed hardly worth speaking of. the baby had turned pale but did not cry. no one knew that anything was wrong. it would have been a pity to let anything trouble such a day. such a procession said a shrill but soft and not unpleasant voice and a person no larger than a child was seen. i know her majesty well and i love her and her child. and since you dropped him on the marble stairs i choose to take him for my own. cried the group laughing. the little old woman paid no attention and her soft grey eyes were fixed on the prince who smiled back at her. everybody started. they listened. the queen her majesty was dead. when the little prince was carried back to his mothers room there was no mother to kiss him. as for his godmother the little old woman in grey nobody knew what became of her. chapter ii. it could not be said that the prince missed his mother children of his age cannot do that but somehow after she died everything seemed to go wrong with him. this happened so many times that at last people began to talk about it. a prince and not able to stand on his legs what a misfortune to the country no one talked of this to the king for he was very sad. the king desired that the prince should keep the name given him by the little old woman in grey and so he was known as dolor. only once when the king and his brother were sitting together with prince dolor playing in a corner of the room dragging himself about with his arms rather than his legs it seemed to strike the father that all was not right with his son. said he suddenly to the nurse. the prince turned to his father a small sweet grave face like his mothers and the king smiled and held out his arms. they came and agreed in what had been pretty well known before that the prince must have been hurt when he was an infant. did anybody remember no nobody. soon after he said this the king died as suddenly and quietly as the queen had done and prince dolor was left without either father or mother as sad a thing as could happen even to a prince. he was more than that now though. he was a king. if anybody had said that prince dolors uncle was cruel he would have said that what he did was for the good of the country. soon after he obtained an order to send the king away which was done in great state. they brought the coffin back in great state and buried him with his parents. chapter iii. and what of the little lame prince whom everybody seemed so easily to have forgotten not everybody. not a bush not a tree not a resting place for bird or beast in that dreary plain. it was not a pleasant place to live. the only sign that human creatures had ever been near the spot was a large round tower which rose up in the centre of the plain. its height was nearly a hundred feet. whatever mystery there was about the tower it and the sky and the plain kept to themselves. this in order that she might take the utmost care of him for those who put him there were equally afraid of his dying and of his living. and yet he was only a little gentle boy with a sweet smile. he was very tired with his long journey and was clinging to the mans neck for he was rather frightened. the tired little boy was prince dolor. he was not dead at all. the man descended the ladder took it to pieces and disappeared across the plain. he always saw the prince so as to make sure that the child was alive and well and then went away until the following month. his nurse was very kind to him though she was a wicked woman. perhaps it made her better to be shut up with an innocent child. byandby he began to learn lessons not that his nurse had been ordered to teach him but she did it partly to amuse herself. she was not a stupid woman and prince dolor was by no means a stupid child so they got on very well. as they told him of the things in the outside world he longed to see them. from this time a change came over the boy. he began to look sad and thin and to shut himself up for hours without speaking. his nurse had been forbidden on pain of death to tell him anything about himself. he had been reading one day but feeling all the while that to read about things which you never can see is like hearing about a beautiful dinner while you are starving. not a very cheerful view just the plain and the sky but he liked it. he used to think if he could only fly out of that window up to the sky or down to the plain how nice it would be perhaps when he died his nurse had told him once in anger that he would never leave the tower till he died he might be able to do this. asked prince dolor in surprise. the little old woman sighed and glanced down at his legs and feet which he did not know were different from those of other children and then to his sweet bright face. it was i who gave you yours and you will belong to me all your days. so they sat down and played and talked together. asked the little old woman. his godmother took him in her arms and kissed him. i only want you. when the door opened prince dolor shut his eyes opening them again nobody but his nurse was in the room as his godmother had melted away. said she kicking a little bundle that lay beside them. chapter iv. it seemed but a mere piece of cloth dark green in color being worn and shabby though not dirty. prince dolor  mistress mary quite contrary 
mary had liked to look at her mother from a distance and she had thought her very pretty but as she knew very little of her she could scarcely have been expected to love her or to miss her very much when she was gone. if she had been older she would no doubt have been very anxious at being left alone in the world but she was very young and as she had always been taken care of she supposed she always would be. she did not want to stay. presently he got rather interested and suddenly made a suggestion. he danced round and round her and made faces and sang and laughed. you have none. you are going to your uncle. girls never do. i heard father and mother talking about him. he lives in a great big desolate old house in the country and no one goes near him. hes so cross he wont let them and they wouldnt come if he would let them. she was a stout woman with very red cheeks and sharp black eyes. mary did not like her at all but as she very seldom liked people there was nothing remarkable in that besides which it was very evident mrs. medlock did not think much of her. what sort of a place was it and what would he be like she had never seen one. perhaps there were none in india. she had begun to wonder why she had never seemed to belong to anyone even when her father and mother had been alive. she had had servants and food and clothes but no one had taken any notice of her. she did not know that this was because she was a disagreeable child but then of course she did not know she was disagreeable. she often thought that other people were but she did not know that she was so herself. she thought mrs. medlock the most disagreeable person she had ever seen with her common highly colored face and her common fine bonnet. it would have made her angry to think people imagined she was her little girl. but mrs. medlock was not in the least disturbed by her and her thoughts. she never dared even to ask a question. the child is to be brought here. she frowned because she remembered that her father and mother had never talked to her about anything in particular. certainly they had never told her things. she did not say any more for a few moments and then she began again. the house is six hundred years old and its on the edge of the moor and theres near a hundred rooms in it though most of thems shut up and locked. mary had begun to listen in spite of herself. it all sounded so unlike india and anything new rather attracted her. but she did not intend to look as if she were interested. that was one of her unhappy disagreeable ways. so she sat still. hes not it seemed quite proper that other people should wait on one. the station was a small one and nobody but themselves seemed to be getting out of the train. she sat and looked out of the window curious making a singular wild low rushing sound. the road went up and down and several times the carriage passed over a little bridge beneath which water rushed very fast with a great deal of noise. mrs. a merry christmas 
jo was the first to wake in the gray dawn of christmas morning. then she opened her new book and began to read. jo put her arm round her and leaning cheek to cheek read also with the quiet expression so seldom seen on her restless face. come amy lets do as they do. asked meg as she and jo ran down to thank her for their gifts half an hour later. she added as the little flask did not appear. march. cried jo taking one up. asked meg surprised to see by her hood and cloak that lazy amy had been out so early. i didnt mean anyone should know till the time came. many of them thank you for our books. cold. asked beth eagerly. they were soon ready and the procession set out. fortunately it was early and they went through back streets so few people saw them and no one laughed at the queer party. how the big eyes stared and the blue lips smiled as the girls went in. said the poor woman crying for joy. in a few minutes it really did seem as if kind spirits had been at work there. the girls meantime triumph of a united humanity over nature had followed another. and the harvest was what i saw it was natural on that golden evening that i should jump at the idea of a social paradise. for after the that i was awakened about dawn. i tried to get to sleep again but i felt restless and uncomfortable. and up the hill i thought i could see ghosts. they moved hastily. i did not see what became of and then i remembered that strange terror of the dark. i put out my hand and touched something soft. at once the eyes darted sideways and something white ran past me. but as i say it went too fast for me to see distinctly. after an instants pause i followed it into the second heap of ruins. a sudden thought came to me. it made me shudder. it was so like a human spider then the light burned my fingers and fell out of my hand going out as it dropped and when i had lit another the little monster had disappeared. but they were interested by my matches and i struck some to amuse them. i tried them again about the well and again i failed. so presently i left them meaning to go back to weena and see what i could get from her. my explanation may be absolutely wrong. that i could see clearly enough already. for i felt sure it was they who had taken it. and why were they so terribly afraid of the dark at first she would not understand my questions and presently she refused to answer them. they were the only tears except my own i ever saw in that golden age. yet i could not face the mystery. if only i had had a companion it would have been different. i dont know if you will understand my feeling but i never felt quite safe at my back. at first she watched me in amazement. for a moment i hung by one hand and after that experience i did not dare to rest again. but even while i turned this over in my mind i continued to descend. it was not too soon. the view i had of it was as much as one could see in the burning of a match. i fancied i heard the breathing of a crowd of those dreadful little beings about me. i shouted at them as loudly as i could. they started away and then i could feel them approaching me again. they clutched at me more boldly whispering odd sounds to each other. this time they were not so seriously alarmed and they made a queer laughing noise as they came back at me. i had the greatest difficulty in keeping my hold. i fell upon my face. even the soil smelt sweet and clean. before i had felt as a man might feel who had fallen into a pit my concern was with the pit and how to get out of it. now i felt like a beast in a trap whose enemy would come upon him soon. it was the darkness of the new moon. it was not now such a very difficult problem to guess what the coming dark nights might mean. i tried to recall the form of it. i had a vague sense of something familiar but i could not tell what it was at the time. i at least would defend myself. i felt i could never sleep again until my bed was secure from them. i shuddered with horror to think how they must already have examined me. you know that great pause that comes upon things before the dusk to me there is always an air of expectation about that evening stillness. well that night the expectation took the colour of my fears. and why had they taken my time machine the clear blue of the distance faded and one star after another came out. the ground grew dim and the trees black. then as the darkness grew deeper she put her arms round my neck and closing her eyes tightly pressed her face against my shoulder. i hesitated at this. i could see no end to it either to the right or the left. the hillside was quiet and deserted but from the black of the wood there came now and then a stir of living things. above me shone the stars for the night was very clear. i felt a certain sense of friendly comfort in their twinkling. then i thought of the great fear that was between the two species and for the first time with a sudden shiver came the clear knowledge of what the meat i had seen might be. yet it was too horrible indeed i had seen none upon the hill that night. we soon met others of the dainty ones laughing and dancing in the sunlight as though there was no such thing in nature as the night. and then i thought once more of the meat that i had seen. i tried to look at the thing in a scientific spirit. why should i trouble myself and there was weena dancing at my side but this attitude of mind was impossible. that necessity was immediate. weena i had resolved to bring with me to our own time. she always seemed to me i fancy more human than she was perhaps because her affection was so human. the place was very silent. as for the rest of the contents of that gallery though on the whole they were the best preserved of all i saw i had little interest. so suddenly that she startled me. then i saw that the gallery ran down at last into a thick darkness. i called to mind that it was already far advanced in the afternoon and that i had still no weapon no refuge and no means of making a fire. but it was impossible somehow to feel any humanity in the things. very eagerly i tried them. they were perfectly good. they were not even damp. i turned to weena. dance i cried to her in her own tongue. for now i had a weapon indeed against the horrible creatures we feared. i could not carry both however and my bar of iron promised best against the bronze gates. then came a doubt. i hesitated. towards sunset i began to consider our position. but that troubled me very little now. in the morning there was the getting of the time machine. i laughed at that and turned again to the dark trees before me. i lit none of my matches because i had no hand free. upon my left arm i carried my little one in my right hand i had my iron bar. but to get one i must put her down. soft little hands too were creeping over my coat and back touching even my neck. then i looked at weena. with a sudden fright i stooped to her. she seemed scarcely to breathe. the wood behind seemed full of the stir and murmur of a great company i had to think rapidly what to do. i lit a match and as i did so two white forms that had been approaching weena dashed hastily away. presently i noticed how dry was some of the foliage above me for since my arrival on the time machine a matter of a week no rain had fallen. i could not even satisfy myself whether or not she breathed. i seemed just to nod and open my eyes. in a moment i knew what had happened. the forest seemed full of the smell of burning wood. i was caught by the neck by the hair by the arms and pulled down. it gave me strength. i struggled up shaking the human rats from me and holding the bar short i thrust where i judged their faces might be. i stood with my back to a tree swinging the iron bar before me. the whole wood was full of the stir and cries of them. a minute passed. yet none came within reach. then suddenly came hope. and close on the heels of that came a strange thing. it was my first fire coming after me. with that i looked for weena but she was gone. it was a close race. this whole space was as bright as day with the reflection of the fire. i was thinking of beginning the fight by killing some of them before this should happen but the fire burst out again brightly and i stayed my hand. but weena was gone. i bit myself and screamed in a passionate desire to awake. i beat the ground with my hands and got up and sat down again and wandered here and there and again sat down. then i would fall to rubbing my eyes and calling upon god to let me awake. it was plain that they had left her poor little body in the forest. now in this old familiar room it is more like the sorrow of a dream than an actual loss. the gay robes of the beautiful people moved hither and thither among the trees. very pleasant was their day as pleasant as the day of the cattle in the field. like the cattle they knew of no enemies and provided against no needs. and their end was the same. once life and property must have reached almost absolute safety. and a great quiet had followed. there is no intelligence where there is no change and no need of change. and when other meat failed them they turned to what old habit had hitherto forbidden. so i say i saw it in my last view of the world of eight hundred and two thousand seven hundred and one. i threw my iron bar away almost sorry not to use it. very calmly i tried to strike the match. one touched me. then came one hand upon me and then another. one indeed they almost got away from me. the clinging hands slipped from me. the darkness presently fell from my eyes. this puzzled me very much at first. all trace of the moon had vanished. the earth had come to rest with one face to the sun even as in our own time the moon faces the earth. the sky was no longer blue. i tried to brush it away with my hand but in a moment it returned and almost immediately came another by my ear. it was drawn swiftly out of my hand. but i was still on the same beach and i saw them distinctly now as soon as i stopped. but i saw nothing moving in earth or sky or sea. i saw this grow larger. silent in another moment the pale stars alone were visible. the sky was absolutely black. i got off the machine to recover myself. i breathed with greater freedom. these too changed and passed and others came. for several minutes i trembled violently. i might have slept there and the whole thing have been a dream. you know the rest. i cannot expect you to believe it. i took my eyes off the time travellers face and looked round at his audience. they were in the dark and little spots of colour swam before them. the others as far as i remember were motionless. the editor stood up with a sigh. the medical man rose came to the come out this way. the time traveller vanished three years ago. and as everybody knows now he has never returned. will he ever return i say for my own part. if that is so it remains for us to live as working day of the week i begin all business and i have always heard that if a thing is well begun it is half done. how beautiful the moon is riding in her silver chariot across the dark blue sky i am proud of my name. the moon is constantly changing and i like change. how white and clean they look hanging on the line school begins on monday and the little children run and laugh on their way to school. every one seems happy that another week has begun. monday likes to begin work but i like to make some progress. they sing and laugh over their work. perhaps mother will bake a special cake for dinner. this is the day young people choose for their wedding day and you dont know how glad i am to be a part of their happiness. i would not change with any of my sister days. the fury of the heavens the crash of falling trees the roaring of waters what can give greater pleasure life and action are my delight. friday. see what wonderful things have happened on my day what great men have been born on friday today the family gather for a story at the twilight hour and all is rest and happiness. saturday. i am the jolly day of the week. the children cry and all day long they sing and call to each other in their games. father comes home earlier today and all go for a walk in the woods or park. the boys play ball and run and shout in their joy. the girls have little parties and cook gives them some fresh cakes. so i wish all people to be happy on saturday the play day of the week. sunday. you have all spoken well my sisters and each one has some claim to be the best day of the week. how fine it is that every day holds some special joy in work or play but you all know the highest joy is mine. i am named for the golden sun that gives light to the world. today the family is united and in the morning with fresh garments and happy faces they seek the knowledge of a higher life. around the dinner table they talk happily together of their work and play and they plan how they may do better work during the next week. love and peace are in all hearts. a desire to help the weak and poor and sad is in every soul. i wish mother would come home im cold and hungry. im tired of scene i. in the wood 
the good fairy. at last i am in this wood where i must save the lady alice from danger. yet it is pleasant to be of service to the young and innocent to those who are good and true. some there are on earth who do not love the truth who do not do the things that are honest and kind and they must be punished. kind and gentle deeds must be rewarded with our help. hark i think i hear the noisy band. here will i hide and listen. this is the hour we love the best. all the serious wise old people who love the day and its work are weary now and have gone to bed. now the moon calls the fairies from brook and fountain to play their merry games and sing. come make a merry ring and dance. no care have we nor fear. break off break off run to your places lest you frighten the traveler whoever it may that light i see my brothers seek me and i will sing to them. perhaps they are not far away and will hear my voice. what sweet song is this can any mortal sing with such charm and beauty ill speak to it lady that you are thus alone lady alice. darkness came upon the grove and i fear they are lost. were they men full grown or still young lady alice. young and fair my brothers are. if these are the lads you seek we can easily find them. lady alice. due west it lies. lady alice. to find it out good shepherd would be too difficult in this darkness to a stranger. gladly will i conduct you and find a lion was awakened from sleep by a mouse running over his face. it happened shortly after this that the lion was caught by some hunters who bound him by strong ropes to the ground. they tried with all their strength and were not able to do it. the wolf and the crane

a dog crossing a bridge over a stream with a piece of flesh in his mouth saw his own shadow in the water and took it for that of another dog with a piece of meat double his own in size. he immediately let go of his own and fiercely attacked the other dog to get his larger piece from him. he thus lost both that which he grasped at in the water because it was a shadow and his own because the stream swept it away. on the day appointed for the race the two started together. the tortoise never for a moment stopped but went on with a slow but steady pace straight to the end of the course. besides i am no crane i am a stork a bird of excellent character and see how i love and slave for my father and mother. the farmer and the snake

my father hid in the hold for six days and nights. he didnt look just exactly like the other bags but it was the best he could do. they lowered a big net into the hold and began moving the bags of wheat. the other sailors looked at the bag too and my father who was in the bag of course tried even harder to look like a bag of wheat. then another sailor felt the bag and he just happened to get couldnt talk for a long while. it scared him that much just thinking about it. this didnt bother my father. he kept walking and slept on the beach again that night. it was a very black night and my father could hardly see the rocks ahead of him. sometimes the rocks were far apart and my father had to get a running start and leap from one to the next. it grew louder and louder as he got nearer to the island. at last it seemed as if he was right on top of the noise and he was. and it never knew my father had jumped on its back by mistake. for seven hours my father climbed and slipped and leapt from rock to rock but while it was still dark he finally reached the very last rock and stepped off onto wild island. the first thing to do he decided was to find the river because the dragon was tied somewhere along its bank. so my father walked until the sun rose and he was quite far from the ocean rocks. my father saw a tiny paw rubbing itself on his knapsack. my father waited a few minutes and began. my father hated to leave the beach but he decided to start along the river bank where at least the jungle wasnt quite so thick. here the jungle was so thick that he could hardly see where the river was. it was very hard to walk in the jungle. once or twice he thought he heard something laughing at him. at last he came out into a clearing and ran right into the middle of it so that he could see anything that might try to attack him. was he surprised when he looked and saw fourteen green eyes coming out of the jungle all around the clearing and when the green eyes turned into seven tigers then the next tiger spoke. said the third tiger. my father thought of the cat and knew this wasnt true. but of course he had too much sense to say so. the tigers went on talking in turn. said the seventh tiger. and they moved in closer. my father looked at those seven hungry tigers and then he had an idea. and they moved so close that he could feel them breathing on his face. all sorts of animals might be using it too but he decided to follow the trail no matter what he met because it might lead to the dragon. but monkeys grandmother died a week ago so they must have seen something else. soon the trail crossed a little brook and my father who by this time was very thirsty stopped to get a drink of water. said a deep angry voice. with that the animal tossed my father up and down over the water. asked my father trying to get his breath and he thought over all the things he had in his pack. but why should i be telling you these things i can hardly believe it dont like it one bit not one bit wont you ever learn the lion yelled at my father. said the lion. and he picked up my father in his front paws to feel how fat he was. said the lion. my father opened the pack and took out the comb and the brush and the seven hair ribbons of different colors. as my father was doing this the lion watched very carefully and began to look much happier. when my father tied on the ribbon he was all smiles. said the lion. as a matter of fact he was so busy that he didnt even know when my father left. he wanted to eat eight or ten but he had only thirteen left and it might be a long time before he could get more. said the other boar now very close to my father. it was the lions mother of course and that thought my father must mean that the dragon was on this side of the river. he hurried on but it was farther away than he had judged. he finally came to the river bank in the late afternoon and looked all around but there was no dragon anywhere in sight. he must have gone back to the other side. said a huge voice. said the six little monkeys. my father makes a bridge 
my father walked back and forth along the bank trying to think of some way to cross the river. what a life for a baby dragon the pole was very high and even if he could get to the top without being seen hed have to go all the way across hand over hand. he looked all around in the water but it was dusk now and he couldnt see anything there. a pale moon came out from behind the clouds and my father could see where the voice was coming from. the crocodiles head was just peeping out of the water. said the crocodile. the crocodile who had first spoken swam up and tasted it. he said. asked my father. its a trick kill it its over there now see my father didnt have a moment to spare. by now the dragon realized that my father was coming to rescue him. im right here can you see me theyre all coming over well make it. he looked around and saw something which surprised and delighted him. all the rest did the same thing one right after the other until they were all swimming away in a line. my father and the dragon laughed themselves weak because it was such a silly sight. he was the most excited baby dragon that ever lived. said the dragon. but my father and the dragon knew that nothing in the world would ever make them go back to wild island. the end

stretched himself and looked out of the window and emotion seized him. for all his journey the south had seemed to welcome him but here at last was the country he knew. the train had evidently been there for some time and there were no signs of an immediate departure. what was the hurry there was plenty of time. it was sufficient to have come to his own land the actual walls of home could wait. the question had been a mere matter of form. gideon had made up his mind and if he had been told that they started in five minutes he would not have changed it. the river was not far away. he would get into loose shoes again old ones if money could buy them and old clothes too. as long as he moved at all he was satisfied. his conscience did not trouble him at all. once he awoke. once ashore again however he began to prepare his breakfast with some haste. for the first time in his journey he was feeling a sense of loneliness and a longing for his kind. he was still happy but his laughter began to seem strange to him in the solitude. it was human beyond a doubt. the leaves parted and a smiling face as black as gideons own regarded him in shy amusement. she was merely trying its sound. gideon followed her slowly. her romantic coming and her romantic name pleased him and too he thought her beautiful. a womans voice sounded thin and far away. asked gideon. the girl shook her head. she girls had a little pair of scissors to cut off twigs and very proud they all were when they brought some wood home to their mother to use in the house. one day however their father told them they him and that she would never see him again. he looked up and there quite close to him in a little clearing where the trees had been cut down by some other woodcutter he saw four beautiful young girls dear ones are. we shall just wish them everything they want and they will get it. and the first thing to be done is to give you some food. he began by cutting a branch from a tree and with it he swept the floor of what was to be the diningroom. then he looked about for the food but he could see nothing but a great big pitcher standing in the shade of a tree the branches of which hung over the clearing. you see that big pitcher. well we get all our food and everything else we want out of it. we just have to wish as we put our hands in and there it is. its a magic pitcher the only one there is in the whole wide world. down he threw his axe and hastened to put his hand in the pitcher wishing for the food he was used to. the fairies often went off together leaving him alone only coming back to the clearing when they wanted something out of the pitcher. the woodcutter got all kinds of things he fancied for himself but presently he began to wish he had his wife and children with him courage and felt sure that the raja would soon find he could not get on without him. it might go hardly with them if he suffered harm at their hands. in his heart however he knew full well that it quite free. she obeyed fully understanding now what all these preparations were for. it had done its duty well and he would not throw it away. the rest of the day he spent quietly in his own home with his wife keeping out of sight of his servants lest they should report his return to his master. all this time the raja was feeling very unhappy for he thought he had himself caused the death of the one man he could trust. what then was his relief and surprise when a message was brought to him that the vizier was at the door of the palace and begged for an interview. the attendants looked on eager to know how he had got down from the tower some of them anything but glad to see him back. he grew richer and richer but he was never really happy again remembering the lie he had told to the master to whom he owed so much. she kept her promise never to tell anyone what really happened but the secret came out for all that. his wife was dead and all his children were getting their own living so he had nothing to do but to look after himself. he led a very easy existence but took a great interest in the affairs of his neighbours. then he hid himself behind the trunk of the tree from which the crow was watching evidently intending to stop there and see what would happen. he was quite right and it was not long before just what he expected came to pass. alas their joy was short lived the crow and the man behind the tree kept very quiet watching them the man with his stick ready to beat the poor helpless birds to death the crow watching out of mere curiosity. now a very agreed never to part again. look how different it is for me it is almost impossible for any of the wild creatures who live near this river to hurt me and they know it full well. strange to say the hunters did not follow the deer and it was evident that they had not noticed the way he had gone. the tortoise the crow and the mouse were all very sorry for the deer and as was always the case the received that he agreed to stop with the three friends and for some weeks after his arrival all went well. the crow always had the most to say and was very useful to the deer in warning him of the presence of hunters in the forest. one beautiful moonlight night the deer did not come back as usual and the other three became very anxious about him. the crow flew up to the highest tree near and eagerly sought for some sign of his lost friend of whom he had grown very fond. he praised the mouse and declared that he would never again look down upon him. great was his rage when he found the net lying on the ground but not exactly where he had left it. he guessed at once that some animal had been caught in it and escaped after a long struggle. so he suspected just what had happened and began to search about for any creature who could have done the mischief. when the tortoise in his turn did not come home the deer the crow and the mouse were very much concerned. they talked the matter over together and decided that however great the risk to themselves they must go back and see what had become of their friend. once more the little mouse showed his wisdom. the hunter rushed after him and the two were soon out of sight. that evening the four friends met once more and talked over all they had gone through together. he is small and weak it is true but he has better brains than any of the rest of us and i for one admire him with all my heart. they once more agreed never to part and lived happily together for many years as they had done ever since they first met. a certain man named harisarman who lived in a little village in india where there were no rich people and everyone had to work hard to get his daily bread got very weary of the life he had to lead. unfortunately he was not a bit industrious but very lazy and so was his wife. neither of them made any attempt to teach their boys and girls to earn their own living and if the other poor people in the village had not helped them they would have starved. in course of time they came to a big town and harisarman went boldly to the chief house in it leaving his wife and children outside. he asked to see the master and was taken into his presence. he said that he would find work for him and his wife and that the children could be sent to a farm he had in the country where they could be made very useful. she became in fact quite a different creature and began to wish she had been a better mother to her children. on the other hand she forgot all about her husband and scarcely ever saw him. it was all very different with harisarman himself. he had no special duties to perform and nobody seemed to want him. if he went into the kitchen the busy servants ordered him to get out of their way and he was not made welcome by the owner of the house or his guests. the merchant too forgot all about him and he felt very lonely and miserable. all of a sudden an idea came into his head. now what can i take that harisarman for a long time. but presently something happened which seemed likely to get him into very great trouble. poor harisarman did not know what to say or do. hearing this harisarman though more there were once upon a time a king and queen who had no children and they took it so much to heart that they hardly ever had a happy moment. but he felt he could have no enjoyment out of it all since he did not know what would become of it after his time. when the time came the queen had a beautiful baby girl the year after she had another and the third year she also had a girl. the king and queen were glad beyond all measure but although the king was very happy he did not forget to set a watch at the palace door so that the princesses should not get out. as they grew up they became both fair and beautiful and all went well with them in every way. their only sorrow was that they were not allowed to go out and play like other children. the sun was shining and everything looked so green and beautiful that they felt that they must go out happen what might. well he didnt think it looked much like it either and if they must go they had better go the soldier said but it must only be for a minute and he himself would go with them and look after them. it was many times prettier than any they had gathered so they must have that also. you can well understand there were plenty who wanted to mr. red squirrel comes to live in the forest 
life in the forest is very different from life in the meadow and the forest people have many ways of doing which are not known in the world outside. they are a quiet people and do not often talk or sing when there are strangers near. then if you were to live among them and speak their language you would find that there are many things about which it is not polite to talk. and there is a reason for all this. it is not because they are cross or selfish or bad. it is just because of the way in which they have to live and hunt and they cannot help it any more than you could help having eyes of a certain color. when people are born there they learn these things without thinking about it but when they come there from some other place it is very hard for everybody thinks it stupid in strangers to ask about such simple matters. when mr. red squirrel first came to the forest he knew nothing of the way in which they do and he afterward said that learning forest manners was even harder than running away from his old home. you see mr. red squirrel was born in the forest but was carried away from there when he was only a baby. one day he saw another squirrel outside a dainty little one who looked as though she had never a sad thought. the next day mr. red squirrel pretended to be sick. he would not run in the wheel or taste the food in his cage. the window was up and when he saw his chance mr. red squirrel leaped into the open air and was away to the forest. his poor legs were weak from living in such a small cage but how he ran the forest was a new world to him and he asked many questions of a fat old gray squirrel. the gray squirrel was one of those people who know a great deal and think that they know a great great deal and want others to think so too. asked mr. red know. he had a very happy life among the forest people and perhaps that was one reason. and after all you know it would have been very foolish to ask questions which nobody could answer and worse than once upon a time there were three bears who lived together in a house of their own in a wood. and while they were walking a little old woman came to the house. the door was not fastened because the bears were good bears who did nobody any harm and never suspected that anybody would harm them. so the little old woman opened the door and went in and well pleased she was when she saw the porridge on the table. so first she tasted the porridge of the great huge bear and that was too hot for her and she said a bad word about that. and then she tasted the porridge of the middle bear and that was too cold for her and she said a bad word about that too. and the naughty old woman said a wicked word about that too. and first she lay down upon the bed of the great huge bear but that was too high at the head for her. and next she lay down upon the bed of the middle bear and that was too high at the foot for her. and then she lay down upon the bed of the little small wee bear and that was neither too high at the head nor at the foot but just right. so she covered herself up comfortably and lay there till she fell fast asleep. by this time the three bears thought their porridge would be cool enough so they came home to breakfast. now the little old woman had left the spoon of the great huge bear standing in his porridge. and when the middle bear looked at his he saw that the spoon once upon a time there was a boy whose name was jack and he lived with his mother on a common. so they called him lazy jack. his mother could not get him to do anything for her and at last told him one monday that if he did not begin to work for his porridge she would turn him out to get his living as he could. in the evening jack took the cheese and went home with it on his head. now she had never laughed in her life and the doctors said she would never speak till somebody made her laugh. they lived in a large house and jacks mother lived with them in great happiness until she died. then once upon a time and a very good time it was though it wasnt in my time nor in your time nor any one elses time there was a girl whose mother had died and her father had married again. and her stepmother hated her because she was more beautiful than herself and she was very cruel to her. she used to make her do all the servants work and never let her have any peace. well the girl started off and asked every one she met to tell her where was the well of the worlds end. but nobody knew and she didnt know what to do when a queer little old woman all bent double told her where it was and how she could get to it. so she did what the old woman told her and at last arrived at the well of the worlds end. the stepmother was fine and angry but she said nothing at all. so the girl went and opened the door and there was the frog from the well of the worlds end. when she got there he told her that he had something to teach her for that in his house he had his own names for things. in the midst of all his glory his queen died leaving behind her an only daughter about fifteen years of age who for her beauty and kindness was the wonder of all that knew her. then up came a second and a third head saying the same as the former. she had not travelled long before she saw a king hunting in the park with his nobles. the king her father was at first astonished that his daughter had been so fortunate till the young king let him know of all that had happened. being now all over blood she searched for water to wash herself and looking round she saw the well. he said that he flew in the air and lived in the trees. the judge therefore decided in favour of the owl. arrived there she found the dead man but the ring was difficult to remove so she drew it off with her teeth. he gave no reason for having thus said and returned to his home. the young girl called her parents and told them the message of the crows. these became a man and a woman. the real mother

there was once a rajah who had six daughters none of whom were married although all were grown up. one day he called them to him and asked each in turn whether she was satisfied with her lot in life and what fate had given to her. now the princess was very religious so she spent her time in reading and said her prayers five times a day believing that if it were her fate to die she would die but if not some help would be sent to her. after she had eaten and drunk she washed the brass vessels in which her food had come and continued to pray and give thanks to god. one day the king her father riding by that way was greatly surprised when he saw what a beautiful house and garden had been made in the midst of the jungle. the rajah was indeed surprised and hastened to find out for himself whether or not the news were true. when the princess met him she reminded him of what she had said about fate and her belief that what was to be would be in spite of all efforts to prevent it so that the rajah also was convinced that she was right. not long afterwards the rajah made up his mind to travel and asked each of his five children what they would like him to bring her on his return. they all wanted something different and he had almost forgotten to ask his youngest daughter what she wanted as she already had all that heart could wish but he felt ashamed to leave her out so he asked a daughter was once born to a brahmin and his wife and from the day of its birth a dog came daily and laid down in the house. here she sat down and told the dog she was thirsty. as she approached the a rajah had two sons. the rajah full of pity threw a stone at the snake and it immediately released the frog which hopped away. the rajah agreed and his new servant followed him. the frog meantime had also gone home and told his wife of the narrow escape he had from the snake and how a man had saved him from its very jaws. so he also took the form of a man and offered himself as a servant to the rajah. then they entered a city belonging to a great king and the three of them offered to work for him. to this the king agreed and they were employed by him. so quickly taking his old form he dived into the water and restored the ring to his master who took it to the king. some time after this the kings daughter was bitten by a snake and in great danger of death. this so delighted the king that he called the young rajah and offered him his daughter in marriage as a reward. so the marriage took place and they lived happily ever afterwards. next time the shoemaker visited his garden he saw a beautiful woman in it and not knowing that she was a fairy asked her to tell him her name and how she came there. even his own mother could not influence him in the matter and so he was released. so all night long the stranger used to pace up and down the palace grounds keeping watch. asked the rajah. so the man turned to do his bidding. outside the garden gate sat a figure covered and clothed in loose white garments. asked the man. now the rajah who had heard every word of the interview quickly returned to the spot where he had first heard the voice and there awaited his servants return. asked he when he saw him. then the rajah left him and ordered him to appear at his court the following day. that night when he began to cry and howl it was at once discovered that he was only a jackal so all the animals ran at him bit him and turned him out. the enchanted bird music and stream

long long ago there lived an old farmer and his wife who had made their home in the mountains far from any town. so he lay in wait day after day and night after night with a big club hoping to catch the badger but all in vain. the badger was in great distress for he did not at all like the idea of being made into soup that night and he thought and thought for a long time trying to hit upon some plan by which he might escape. she looked tired and old. wont you let me do that for you i am so tired and sore tied up like this. the old woman had a good and simple nature and could not think badly days passed happily and quietly with her father. the story of the man who did not wish to die. long long ago there lived a man called sentaro. one day without any reason whatsoever the thought of death and sickness came to him. the idea of falling ill or dying made him very wretched. he could not get away from it. whoever drank of this wonderful draught lived forever. the crane grew large enough for him to ride on it with comfort. it then spread its wings rose high in the air and flew away over the mountains right out to sea. sentaro was at first quite frightened but by degrees he grew accustomed to the swift flight through the air. on and on they went for thousands of miles. after several days they reached an island. as soon as sentaro got down from the birds back the crane folded up of its own accord and flew into his pocket. he walked first round about the country and then through the town. everything was of course quite strange and different from his own land. he had wished to escape from dying. these they swallowed eagerly hoping for death to come so that they might go to paradise. he never saw any one ill after eating these horrible things nor did he ever see any one with as much as a cold. sentaro was delighted. he was the only happy man on the island. for his part he wished to live thousands of years and to enjoy life. he set himself up in business and for the present never even dreamed of going back to his native land. this caused him great annoyance. time passed like the flight of an arrow for him for he was busy from morning till night. no sooner did he pray than the paper crane popped out of his pocket. once more the bird grew and grew till it was large enough for him to mount it. as he did so the bird spread its wings and flew swiftly out across the sea in the direction of japan. he tried to stop the bird in vain. the crane held on its way for thousands of miles across the ocean. sentaro fell with it. he looked round but there was no ship in sight. suddenly a bright light came towards him and in the light stood a messenger. but you grew weary of living there and begged to be allowed to return to your native land so that you might die. the angel disappeared as soon as he had finished speaking and sentaro took the lesson to heart. he was very poor and sad also for no child had heaven sent to cheer his old age and in his heart there was no hope of rest from work till he died and was laid in the quiet grave. for three days the festival was kept up with song and dance and music. then they approached the house and tried to speak to the old man and his wife or some of the servants but not even this was granted them. still in spite of all this disappointment they stayed on day after day and night after night and counted it as nothing winter passed. the snow and frost and the cold winds gradually gave place to the gentle warmth of spring. thus several days passed but even so they could not rest in their homes. then he told her how in the first days of her illness the father and daughter thought that it was only a cold and were not particularly anxious. but in spite of all their efforts the womans life was not to be saved. i am continued to cry. i see that your fur is all pulled out and that your skin is quite bare. then he went on to say how he had been deceived by a party of men who looked very like his kind friend and the hare ended his long tale of woe by begging the man to give him some medicine that would cure him and make his fur grow again. the hare was very glad to be told what to do so kindly. to his amazement even while he was doing this he saw his nice white fur growing again the pain ceased and he felt just as he had done before all his misfortunes. it is my earnest wish to do something for you in return. how kind you have been to me i am quite sure that the princess whom your brothers have gone to seek will refuse to be the bride of any of them and will prefer you for your goodness of heart. he found them just entering the princesss gate. this is the end of the story. from his childhood he proved himself to be of remarkable strength wisdom and courage and his father noticed with pride that he gave promise of great things and he loved him even more than he did his elder son. even then there was no man who could rival him for courage and bold deeds and he received his fathers command with great joy. he now met with great difficulties for he found the country exceedingly wild and rough. it was all but impossible to go on. we cannot clear the roads and fight as well. with her help he put on the robe and let his hair down till it flowed over his shoulders. he smiled as he gazed at himself the disguise was so perfect. he hardly knew himself so changed was he. all traces of the warrior had disappeared and in the shining surface only a beautiful lady looked back at him. little did they dream that it was their enemy whose coming they so dreaded who now stood before them in this disguise. this was the moment for which the brave prince had been waiting. hitherto i believed that my dead brother and i were the strongest men in the land and that there was no one who could overcome us. you are indeed a strong man to have so easily overcome us. allow me to give you a new name. he seized quickly what he thought was his sword and stood on guard to defend himself. alas even if his efforts had been successful the sword would have been of no use to him for it was of wood. when he returned to the capital the king praised him for his brave deeds and held a feast in the palace in honor of his safe coming home and presented him with many rare gifts. but the prince was not allowed to live an idle life long. the king decided that it was necessary to send an army to do battle with them and bring them to reason. but who was to lead the men these she presented to him as a parting gift. when these were over the governor told his guest that his country was famous for its fine deer and proposed a deer hunt for the princes amusement. at the same time the grass on his left and right burst into flames and these began to spread swiftly towards him on all sides. he looked round for a chance of escape. there was none. he was surrounded by fire. he determined to die if that were necessary fighting for his life and not standing still waiting for death to come to him. her garments were dainty and bright and her skin was white as snow for she had never known what it was to be weary along the path of duty or to walk in the heat of a summers sun. this is only a brook why do you men want so many boats his heart was softened at the remembrance of her and he never allowed her to pass from his thoughts even for a moment. oh my wife my wife many homes had been made desolate and the men were afraid to go out to their daily work in the fields or the women to go to the rivers to wash their rice. it is indeed a matter for wonder that here in this place so near the capital a wicked monster has dared to take up his abode and be the terror of the kings subjects. he climbed up a good distance when all of a sudden at a winding in the path a monster serpent appeared before him and stopped the way. now a sudden darkness came over the mountain and rain began to fall so that for the gloom and the rain the prince could hardly see which way to take. long long ago there lived an old man and an old woman they were peasants and had to work hard to earn their daily rice. the old woman at last found a nice spot by the river bank and put her basket down. then she set to work to wash the clothes she took them one by one out of the basket and washed them in the river and rubbed them on the stones. she said to herself. she stretched out her arm to try and get bundle of grass on his back so big that he was almost hidden and she could hardly see him. asked the old man wondering at her unusual eagerness. it felt even heavier than before. and she told him the truth. heaven has had compassion on you. on hearing this the old man and his wife were very happy. they had cried night and day for sorrow at having no child to help them in their lonely old age and now that their prayer was answered they were so lost with joy that they did not know where to put their hands or their feet. the years passed quickly by and the child grew to be fifteen years of age. the old couples pleasure was very great when they looked at him for he was just what they thought a hero ought to be like. the old man was much surprised at hearing all this from a mere boy of fifteen. he thought it best to let the boy go. you may go if you wish. he was full of courage and did not know what fear was. the old man and woman at once set to work to pound rice in the kitchen i have behaved in a very stupid way. said the dog. then momotaro got up and the dog followed. as they were going along an animal came down from a tree a little ahead of them. you are welcome in this once upon a time there lived a very rich man and a king besides whose name was midas and he had a little daughter whom nobody but myself ever heard of and whose name i either never knew or have entirely forgotten. but the more midas loved his daughter the more did he desire and seek for wealth. he thought foolish man thus he gave all his thoughts and all his time to this one purpose. it was here that he kept his wealth. midas called himself a happy man but felt that he was not yet quite so happy as he might be. now i need hardly remind such wise little people as you are that in the old old times when king midas was alive a great many things came to pass which we should consider wonderful if they were to happen in our own day and country. and on the other hand a great many things take place nowadays which seem not only wonderful to us but at which the people of old times would have stared their eyes out. it is no matter about telling you who he was. midas had met such beings before now and was not sorry to meet one of them again. it was far more probable that he came to do midas a favor. he observed. exclaimed the stranger. midas shook his head. asked the stranger. at last a bright idea occurred to king midas. exclaimed he. said midas. asked midas. whether midas slept as usual that night the story does not say. at any rate day had hardly peeped over the hills when king midas was broad awake and stretching his arms out of bed began to touch the objects that were within reach. he was anxious to prove whether the golden touch had really come according to the strangers promise. he took up a book from the table. midas now took his spectacles from his pocket and put them on his nose in order that he might see more distinctly what he was about. in those days spectacles for common people had not been invented but were already worn by kings else how could midas have had any to his great perplexity however excellent as the glasses were he discovered that he could not possibly see through them. but midas knew a way to make them far more precious according to his way of thinking than roses had ever been before. by the time this good work was completed king midas was summoned to breakfast and as the morning air had given him an excellent appetite he made haste back to the palace. at all events this is a breakfast fit to set before a king and whether he had it or not king midas could not have had a better. to do midas justice he really loved his daughter and loved her so much the more this morning on account of the good fortune which had befallen him. cried midas. exclaimed her father. as soon as i was dressed i ran into the garden to gather some roses for you because i know you like them and like them the better when gathered by your little daughter. but oh dear dear me what do you think has happened such a misfortune said midas. and what was to be done would he be less so by dinner time but this was only a passing thought. she sat a moment gazing at her father and trying with all the might of her little wits to find out what was the matter with him. he bent down and kissed her. he felt that his little daughters love was worth a thousand times more than he had gained by the golden touch. cried he. alas what had he done how fatal was the gift which the stranger bestowed oh terrible misfortune except when his eyes were fixed on the image he could not possibly believe that she was changed to gold. this however could not be. midas shook his head. exclaimed the stranger. have i not faithfully kept my promise with you observed the stranger. exclaimed midas. said the stranger looking seriously at him. were it so your case would indeed be desperate. replied midas. a fly settled on his nose but immediately fell to the floor for it too had become gold. midas shuddered. he was conscious also of a change within himself. a cold hard and heavy weight seemed to have gone out of his bosom. the curse of the golden touch had therefore really been removed from him. no sooner did it fall on her than you would have laughed to see how the rosy color came back to the dear childs cheek and how astonished she was to find herself dripping wet and her father still throwing more water over her cried she. her father did not think it necessary to tell his beloved child how very foolish he had been but contented himself with there was once a princess the most beautiful princess that ever was seen. she was also wise graceful and gentle so that one would have thought she must be the happiest princess in the world. but alas she could make only three remarks. you may well imagine what a great misfortune this was to a young and lively princess. but this the princess could not endure for she had never yet seen a man whom she was willing to marry. nevertheless she feared her fathers anger for she knew that he always kept his word so that very night she slipped down the back stairs of the palace opened the back door and were not yet over however for a few days later the wind increased till it blew a terrible storm indeed. my horror of mind put me into such a condition that i can by no words describe it. we fired guns for help and a ship who had rid it out just ahead of us ventured a boat out. i embraced the offer and went the voyage with him. it was a prosperous voyage. i was fortunate enough to fall into the hands of a master who treated me with no little kindness. one day he sent me out with a moor to catch fish for him. instead of that however i stepped forward and stooping behind the moor took him by surprise and tossed him overboard. he rose to the surface and called on me to take him in. for reply i presented a gun at him and told him if he came nearer the boat i would shoot him and that as the sea was calm he might easily swim ashore. so he turned about and swam for the shore and i make no doubt but he reached it with ease. on coming nearer they hailed me but i understood not a word. they then bade me come on board and very kindly took me in with all my goods. ii. we were all thrown into the sea and out of fifteen who were on board none escaped but myself. night coming on me i took up my lodging in a tree. i swam out to the ship and found that her stern lay lifted up on the bank. my next work was to view the country. i must not forget that i brought on shore two cats and a dog. he was a trusty servant to me many years. i wanted nothing that he could fetch me nor any company. i only wanted him to talk to me but that he could not do. later i managed to catch a parrot which did much to cheer my loneliness. i now went in search of a place where to fix my dwelling. on the side of this rock was a hollow space like the entrance of a cave before which i resolved to pitch my tent. the entrance i made to be by a short ladder to go over the top and when i was in i lifted the ladder after me. when i had done this i began to work my way into the rock. all the earth and stones i dug out i laid up within my fence and thus i made me a cave just behind my tent which served me like a cellar. i knew not how it came there. at last it occurred to me that i had shaken out the bag there. i kept all this for seed and bore the want of bread with patience. i soon found that i needed many things to make me comfortable. first i wanted a chair and a table for without them i must live like a savage. so i set to work. from the trunk of the tree i cut a log of the length my board was to be. on these i laid my tools and other things. from time to time i made many useful things. i had however one want greater than all the others bread. but for an oven i was indeed in great pain. at length i found out an experiment for that also. it need not be wondered at if all these things took up most of the third year of my abode in the island. i had now brought my state of life to be much easier than it was at first and i learned to look more upon the bright side of my condition and less on the dark. had anyone in england met such a man as i was it must have frightened them or raised great laughter. there was my majesty prince and lord of the whole island. my old dog sat at my right hand and two cats on each side of the table expecting a bit from my hand as a mark of special favour. iii. one day walking along the beach i was exceedingly surprised with the print of a mans naked foot plainly impressed on the sand. i listened i looked around but i could hear nothing nor see anything. i went up to a rising ground to look further i walked backwards and forwards on the shore but i through the brush to keep them in sight. there it stood still shaking its head. there was no time to search for it. the boys shouted to frighten him off. the crazy creature appeared neither to hear nor heed. the boys could no more have moved it than they could move a mountain. moreover it was now beginning to snow fine and fast. the end
